name: Bend, OR
tagline: Outdoor recreation mecca with 300 days of sunshine—but diversity is nearly nonexistent and it's expensive

cost_of_living.index_vs_national: 3% above national average (housing drove it up)

diversity.summary: ⚠️ CRITICAL CONCERN: Bend is 91% White, less than 1% Black (332 Black residents out of 105,000). This is even whiter than Boise. Oregon has a dark racial history (state founded with Black exclusion laws), and Bend reflects that legacy. While the city is politically moderate-liberal and outdoor culture is welcoming, diversity is almost nonexistent. Candace would face extreme isolation. Reddit reports note 'the more diverse it gets the more racist people are being'—concerning.
diversity.notable: One of the whitest cities in America; Oregon's history of racial exclusion still echoes

safety.summary: Generally safe but not exceptional. Violent crime rate around 156 per 100k (below national average), but property crime is higher due to tourism, transient population, and homelessness concerns. Crime fell 13% in 2024. Bend ranks in 32nd percentile for overall safety (safer than 32% of cities). Most neighborhoods feel safe, but not as low-crime as Boise. Would meet Candace's baseline but not exceed it.
safety.violent_crime_rate: ~156 per 100k (low, but property crime is concern)

scenery.summary: Absolutely stunning—Cascade Mountains dominate the skyline, Deschutes River runs through town, high desert landscape with ponderosa pines. Mount Bachelor (ski resort) is 22 miles away, Smith Rock State Park (world-class rock climbing) 30 miles. This is outdoor recreation heaven—hiking, mountain biking, skiing, paddling, climbing all world-class and accessible. Scenery is the draw here.

climate.summary: High desert four-season paradise—over 300 days of sunshine (more than Denver!), dry climate, beautiful summers (80s), snowy winters but sunny. This is Oregon's 'sunny side'—opposite of rainy Portland/Seattle. Cold nights year-round (desert), warm days. Perfect for outdoor enthusiasts. Snow melts fast in town, accumulates in mountains.

culture.summary: Bend culture IS outdoor recreation—this is a town of skiers, mountain bikers, climbers, paddlers, trail runners. Breweries everywhere (10+ craft breweries), food scene growing but small-town, outdoor gear shops, festivals (BendFilm, Pole Pedal Paddle). It's overwhelmingly white, affluent, outdoorsy transplants. Politically moderate—mix of environmentally-conscious liberals and libertarian conservatives. Culture is shallow beyond outdoor pursuits.

pros: Unbeatable outdoor recreation access—skiing, biking, hiking, climbing at world-class level
300+ days of sunshine with four true seasons
Growing food scene and breweries (10+ craft breweries)
Moderate politics (for Oregon)—environmentally progressive but not Portland-level
Josh would be in heaven with outdoor access
cons: ⚠️ DEALBREAKER: 91% white, 0.7% Black—Candace would face severe isolation
Expensive for a small city (driven by outdoor recreation demand)
Very car-dependent outside small downtown core
Culture is one-dimensional (outdoor rec dominates everything)
Small-town limitations—will feel tiny after 1-2 years
Limited diversity in food, arts, perspectives

neighborhoods.name: Downtown Bend
neighborhoods.vibe: Walkable core—boutiques, restaurants, breweries, Deschutes River access
neighborhoods.diversity_notes: Most diverse (still overwhelmingly white), younger crowd
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Most walkable, near river trails, restaurants. Best option if determined to try Bend. Still very white and small.

neighborhoods.name: Old Bend / Central District
neighborhoods.vibe: Historic neighborhood with character homes, tree-lined streets
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Walkable, character, near downtown. Safe and charming but homogeneous. Close to trails and river.

neighborhoods.name: Box Factory District
neighborhoods.vibe: Former industrial area turned trendy—breweries, restaurants, bike shops
neighborhoods.diversity_notes: Younger, outdoor industry workers, very white
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Trendy, walkable, near Deschutes River Trail. Josh would like the vibe. Limited diversity.

neighborhoods.name: Northwest Crossing
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Safe, near trails, new construction. Too suburban and cookie-cutter for their goals. Not recommended.

neighborhoods.name: River West
neighborhoods.vibe: Residential along Deschutes River—outdoor access, established
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Direct river access, trails, safe. More residential. Still very homogeneous. Decent value.
